segment.source: Create a "hello world" app in C++ (Windows 10)
segment.target: Create a "hello world" app in C++ (Windows 10)

segment.source: With Microsoft Visual Studio 2015, you can use C++ to develop an app that runs on Windows 10, including on phones running Windows 10.
segment.target: With Microsoft Visual Studio 2015, you can use C++ to develop an app that runs on Windows 10, including on phones running Windows 10.

segment.source: These apps have a UI that's defined in Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML).
segment.target: These apps have a UI that's defined in Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML).

segment.source: To develop an app that runs on Windows 8.1 and Windows Phone 8.1, use Microsoft Visual Studio 2013 Update 3 or later and follow the steps here.
segment.target: To develop an app that runs on Windows 8.1 and Windows Phone 8.1, use Microsoft Visual Studio 2013 Update 3 or later and follow the steps here.

segment.source: The most significant difference is that for Windows 8.1 and Windows Phone 8.1, you use a solution with three projects, one for the desktop (or tablet device), one for the phone, and one for shared code.
segment.target: The most significant difference is that for Windows 8.1 and Windows Phone 8.1, you use a solution with three projects, one for the desktop (or tablet device), one for the phone, and one for shared code.

segment.source: For Windows 10 development, all code shares the same project.
segment.target: For Windows 10 development, all code shares the same project.

segment.source: For tutorials in other programming languages, see:
segment.target: For tutorials in other programming languages, see:

pc.pc: Create your first Windows Store app using JavaScript
Create your first Windows Store app using JavaScript
Create your first Windows Store app using C\# or Visual Basic
Create your first Windows Store app using C\# or Visual Basic

segment.source: Before you start...
segment.target: Before you start...

segment.source: To complete this tutorial, you must use Visual Studio 2015 Community or later, or one of the non-Community versions of Visual Studio 2015, on a computer that's running Windows 10 or Windows 8.1.
segment.target: To complete this tutorial, you must use Visual Studio 2015 Community or later, or one of the non-Community versions of Visual Studio 2015, on a computer that's running Windows 10 or Windows 8.1.

segment.source: To download, see Get the tools.
segment.target: To download, see Get the tools.

segment.source: Install the appropriate SDK for Windows Universal Platform development.
segment.target: Install the appropriate SDK for Windows Universal Platform development.

segment.source: You also must have a developer license.
segment.target: You also must have a developer license.

segment.source: For instructions, see Get a developer license.
segment.target: For instructions, see Get a developer license.

segment.source: We assume you have a basic understanding of standard C++, XAML, and the concepts in the XAML overview.
segment.target: We assume you have a basic understanding of standard C++, XAML, and the concepts in the XAML overview.

segment.source: We assume you're using the default window layout in Visual Studio.
segment.target: We assume you're using the default window layout in Visual Studio.

segment.source: To reset to the default layout, on the menu bar, choose Window > Reset Window Layout.
segment.target: To reset to the default layout, on the menu bar, choose Window > Reset Window Layout.

segment.source: Note that there is a known issue with Visual Studio 2015 that can result in a NullReferenceException when loading the XAML designer.
segment.target: Note that there is a known issue with Visual Studio 2015 that can result in a NullReferenceException when loading the XAML designer.

segment.source: This issue blocks some of the steps of this tutorial, unless you apply the workaround.
segment.target: This issue blocks some of the steps of this tutorial, unless you apply the workaround.

segment.source: For details about this issue and the workaround, see this MSDN forum post .
segment.target: For details about this issue and the workaround, see this MSDN forum post .

segment.source: Comparing C++ desktop apps to Windows apps
segment.target: Comparing C++ desktop apps to Windows apps

segment.source: If you're coming from a background in Windows desktop programming in C++, you'll probably find that some aspects of Windows Store app and Windows Phone app programming are familiar, but other aspects require some learning.
segment.target: If you're coming from a background in Windows desktop programming in C++, you'll probably find that some aspects of Windows Store app and Windows Phone app programming are familiar, but other aspects require some learning.

segment.source: What's the same?
segment.target: What's the same?

segment.source: You can use the STL, the CRT (with some exceptions), and any other C++ library as long as the code does not attempt to call Windows functions that are not accessible from the Windows Runtime environment.
segment.target: You can use the STL, the CRT (with some exceptions), and any other C++ library as long as the code does not attempt to call Windows functions that are not accessible from the Windows Runtime environment.

segment.source: If you're accustomed to visual designers, you can still use the designer built into Microsoft Visual Studio, or you can use the more full-featured Blend for Visual Studio.
segment.target: If you're accustomed to visual designers, you can still use the designer built into Microsoft Visual Studio, or you can use the more full-featured Blend for Visual Studio.

segment.source: If you're accustomed to coding UI by hand, you can hand-code your XAML.
segment.target: If you're accustomed to coding UI by hand, you can hand-code your XAML.

segment.source: You're still creating apps that use Windows operating system types and your own custom types.
segment.target: You're still creating apps that use Windows operating system types and your own custom types.

segment.source: You're still using the Visual Studio debugger, profiler, and other development tools.
segment.target: You're still using the Visual Studio debugger, profiler, and other development tools.

segment.source: You're still creating apps that are compiled to native machine code by the Visual C++ compiler.
segment.target: You're still creating apps that are compiled to native machine code by the Visual C++ compiler.

segment.source: Windows Store apps in C++ don't execute in a managed runtime environment.
segment.target: Windows Store apps in C++ don't execute in a managed runtime environment.

segment.source: What's new?
segment.target: What's new?

segment.source: The design principles for Windows Store apps and Universal Windows apps are very different from those for desktop apps.
segment.target: The design principles for Windows Store apps and Universal Windows apps are very different from those for desktop apps.

segment.source: Window borders, labels, dialog boxes, and so on, are de-emphasized.
segment.target: Window borders, labels, dialog boxes, and so on, are de-emphasized.

segment.source: Content is foremost.
segment.target: Content is foremost.

segment.source: Great Universal Windows apps incorporate these principles from the very beginning of the planning stage.
segment.target: Great Universal Windows apps incorporate these principles from the very beginning of the planning stage.

segment.source: You're using XAML to define the entire UI.
segment.target: You're using XAML to define the entire UI.

segment.source: The separation between UI and core program logic is much clearer in a Windows Universal app than in an MFC or Win32 app.
segment.target: The separation between UI and core program logic is much clearer in a Windows Universal app than in an MFC or Win32 app.

segment.source: Other people can work on the appearance of the UI in the XAML file while you're working on the behavior in the code file.
segment.target: Other people can work on the appearance of the UI in the XAML file while you're working on the behavior in the code file.

segment.source: You're primarily programming against a new, easy-to-navigate, object-oriented API, the Windows Runtime, although on Windows devices Win32 is still available for some functionality.
segment.target: You're primarily programming against a new, easy-to-navigate, object-oriented API, the Windows Runtime, although on Windows devices Win32 is still available for some functionality.

segment.source: You use C++/CX to consume and create Windows Runtime objects.
segment.target: You use C++/CX to consume and create Windows Runtime objects.

segment.source: C++/CX enables C++ exception handling, delegates, events, and automatic reference counting of dynamically created objects.
segment.target: C++/CX enables C++ exception handling, delegates, events, and automatic reference counting of dynamically created objects.

segment.source: When you use C++/CX, the details of the underlying COM and Windows architecture are hidden from your app code.
segment.target: When you use C++/CX, the details of the underlying COM and Windows architecture are hidden from your app code.

segment.source: For more information, see C++/CX Language Reference.
segment.target: For more information, see C++/CX Language Reference.

segment.source: Your app is compiled into a package that also contains metadata about the types that your app contains, the resources that it uses, and the capabilities that it requires (file access, internet access, camera access, and so forth).
segment.target: Your app is compiled into a package that also contains metadata about the types that your app contains, the resources that it uses, and the capabilities that it requires (file access, internet access, camera access, and so forth).

segment.source: In the Windows Store and Windows Phone Store your app is verified as safe by a certification process and made discoverable to millions of potential customers.
segment.target: In the Windows Store and Windows Phone Store your app is verified as safe by a certification process and made discoverable to millions of potential customers.

segment.source: Hello World Store app in C++
segment.target: Hello World Store app in C++

segment.source: Our first app is a "Hello World" that demonstrates some basic features of interactivity, layout, and styles.
segment.target: Our first app is a "Hello World" that demonstrates some basic features of interactivity, layout, and styles.

segment.source: We'll create an app from the Windows Universal app project template.
segment.target: We'll create an app from the Windows Universal app project template.

segment.source: If you've developed apps for Windows 8.1 and Windows Phone 8.1 before, you might remember that you had to have three projects in Visual Studio, one for the Windows app, one for the phone app, and another with shared code.
segment.target: If you've developed apps for Windows 8.1 and Windows Phone 8.1 before, you might remember that you had to have three projects in Visual Studio, one for the Windows app, one for the phone app, and another with shared code.

segment.source: The Windows 10 Universal Windows Platform (UWP) makes it possible to have just one project, which runs on all devices, including desktop and laptop computers running Windows 10, devices such as tablets, mobile phones, and so on.
segment.target: The Windows 10 Universal Windows Platform (UWP) makes it possible to have just one project, which runs on all devices, including desktop and laptop computers running Windows 10, devices such as tablets, mobile phones, and so on.

segment.source: We'll start with the basics:
segment.target: We'll start with the basics:

segment.source: How to create a Universal Windows project in Visual Studio 2015 or later.
segment.target: How to create a Universal Windows project in Visual Studio 2015 or later.

segment.source: How to understand the projects and files that are created.
segment.target: How to understand the projects and files that are created.

segment.source: How to understand the extensions in Visual C++ component extensions (C++/CX), and when to use them.
segment.target: How to understand the extensions in Visual C++ component extensions (C++/CX), and when to use them.

source.pc: First, create a solution in Visual Studio

target.pc: First, create a solution in Visual Studio

segment.source: In Visual Studio, on the menu bar, choose File > New > Project.
segment.target: In Visual Studio, on the menu bar, choose File > New > Project.

segment.source: In the New Project dialog box, in the left pane, expand Installed > Visual C++ > Windows > Universal.
segment.target: In the New Project dialog box, in the left pane, expand Installed > Visual C++ > Windows > Universal.

segment.source: In the center pane, select Blank App (Universal Windows).
segment.target: In the center pane, select Blank App (Universal Windows).

segment.source: Enter a name for the project.
segment.target: Enter a name for the project.

segment.source: We'll name it HelloWorld.
segment.target: We'll name it HelloWorld.

source.pc: C++ project templates in the New Project dialog box

target.pc: C++ project templates in the New Project dialog box

segment.source: Choose the OK button.
segment.target: Choose the OK button.

segment.source: If this is the first UWP project you've created, and you haven't enabled Developer Mode on your computer, the Enable Developer mode dialog box appears.
segment.target: If this is the first UWP project you've created, and you haven't enabled Developer Mode on your computer, the Enable Developer mode dialog box appears.

segment.source: Click on the link to bring up the Settings page that lets you set Developer Mode.
segment.target: Click on the link to bring up the Settings page that lets you set Developer Mode.

segment.source: Developer Mode allows your apps to be deployed and run locally.
segment.target: Developer Mode allows your apps to be deployed and run locally.

segment.source: Your project files are created.
segment.target: Your project files are created.

segment.source: Before we go on, let’s look at what's in the solution.
segment.target: Before we go on, let’s look at what's in the solution.

source.pc: Univeral app solution with nodes collapsed

target.pc: Univeral app solution with nodes collapsed

segment.source: About the project files
segment.target: About the project files

segment.source: Every .xaml file in a project folder has a corresponding .xaml.h file and .xaml.cpp file in the same folder and a .g file and a .g.hpp file in the Generated Files folder, which is on disk but not part of the project.
segment.target: Every .xaml file in a project folder has a corresponding .xaml.h file and .xaml.cpp file in the same folder and a .g file and a .g.hpp file in the Generated Files folder, which is on disk but not part of the project.

segment.source: You modify the XAML files to create UI elements and connect them to data sources (DataBinding).
segment.target: You modify the XAML files to create UI elements and connect them to data sources (DataBinding).

segment.source: You modify the .h and .cpp files to add custom logic for event handlers.
segment.target: You modify the .h and .cpp files to add custom logic for event handlers.

segment.source: The auto-generated files represent the transformation of the XAML markup into C++.
segment.target: The auto-generated files represent the transformation of the XAML markup into C++.

segment.source: Don't modify these files, but you can study them to better understand how the code-behind works.
segment.target: Don't modify these files, but you can study them to better understand how the code-behind works.

segment.source: Basically, the generated file contains a partial class definition for a XAML root element; this class is the same class that you modify in the \*.xaml.h and .cpp files.
segment.target: Basically, the generated file contains a partial class definition for a XAML root element; this class is the same class that you modify in the \*.xaml.h and .cpp files.

segment.source: The generated files declare the XAML UI child elements as class members so that you can reference them in the code you write.
segment.target: The generated files declare the XAML UI child elements as class members so that you can reference them in the code you write.

segment.source: At build time, the generated code and your code are merged into a complete class definition and then compiled.
segment.target: At build time, the generated code and your code are merged into a complete class definition and then compiled.

segment.source: Let's look first at the project files.
segment.target: Let's look first at the project files.

segment.source: App.xaml, App.xaml.h, App.xaml.cpp: Represent the Application object, which is an app's entry point.
segment.target: App.xaml, App.xaml.h, App.xaml.cpp: Represent the Application object, which is an app's entry point.

segment.source: App.xaml contains no page-specific UI markup, but you can add UI styles and other elements that you want to be accessible from any page.
segment.target: App.xaml contains no page-specific UI markup, but you can add UI styles and other elements that you want to be accessible from any page.

segment.source: The code-behind files contain handlers for the OnLaunched and OnSuspending events.
segment.target: The code-behind files contain handlers for the OnLaunched and OnSuspending events.

segment.source: Typically, you add custom code here to initialize your app when it starts and perform cleanup when it's suspended or terminated.
segment.target: Typically, you add custom code here to initialize your app when it starts and perform cleanup when it's suspended or terminated.

segment.source: MainPage.xaml, MainPage.xaml.h, MainPage.xaml.cpp:Contain the XAML markup and code-behind for the default "start" page in an app.
segment.target: MainPage.xaml, MainPage.xaml.h, MainPage.xaml.cpp:Contain the XAML markup and code-behind for the default "start" page in an app.

segment.source: It has no navigation support or built-in controls.
segment.target: It has no navigation support or built-in controls.

segment.source: pch.h, pch.cpp: A precompiled header file and the file that includes it in your project.
segment.target: pch.h, pch.cpp: A precompiled header file and the file that includes it in your project.

segment.source: In pch.h, you can include any headers that do not change often and are included in other files in the solution.
segment.target: In pch.h, you can include any headers that do not change often and are included in other files in the solution.

segment.source: Package.appxmanifest: An XML file that describes the device capabilities that your app requires, and the app version info and other metadata.
segment.target: Package.appxmanifest: An XML file that describes the device capabilities that your app requires, and the app version info and other metadata.

segment.source: To open this file in the Manifest Designer, just double-click it.
segment.target: To open this file in the Manifest Designer, just double-click it.

segment.source: HelloWorld\_TemporaryKey.pfx:A key that enables deployment of the app on this machine, from Visual Studio.
segment.target: HelloWorld\_TemporaryKey.pfx:A key that enables deployment of the app on this machine, from Visual Studio.

segment.source: A first look at the code
segment.target: A first look at the code

segment.source: If you examine the code in App.xaml.h, App.xaml.cpp in the shared project, you'll notice that it's mostly C++ code that looks familiar.
segment.target: If you examine the code in App.xaml.h, App.xaml.cpp in the shared project, you'll notice that it's mostly C++ code that looks familiar.

segment.source: However, some syntax elements might not be as familiar if you are new to Windows Runtime apps, or you've worked with C++/CLI.
segment.target: However, some syntax elements might not be as familiar if you are new to Windows Runtime apps, or you've worked with C++/CLI.

segment.source: Here are the most common non-standard syntax elements you'll see in C++/CX:
segment.target: Here are the most common non-standard syntax elements you'll see in C++/CX:

segment.source: Almost all Windows Runtime classes, which includes all the types in the Windows API--XAML controls, the pages in your app, the App class itself, all device and network objects, all container types--are declared as a ref class.
segment.target: Almost all Windows Runtime classes, which includes all the types in the Windows API--XAML controls, the pages in your app, the App class itself, all device and network objects, all container types--are declared as a ref class.

segment.source: (A few Windows types are value class or value struct).
segment.target: (A few Windows types are value class or value struct).

segment.source: A ref class is consumable from any language.
segment.target: A ref class is consumable from any language.

segment.source: In C++, the lifetime of these types is governed by automatic reference counting (not garbage collection) so that you never explicitly delete these objects.
segment.target: In C++, the lifetime of these types is governed by automatic reference counting (not garbage collection) so that you never explicitly delete these objects.

segment.source: You can create your own ref classes as well.
segment.target: You can create your own ref classes as well.

segment.source: All Windows Runtime types must be declared within a namespace and unlike in ISO C++ the types themselves have an accessibility modifier.
segment.target: All Windows Runtime types must be declared within a namespace and unlike in ISO C++ the types themselves have an accessibility modifier.

segment.source: The public modifier makes the class visible to Windows Runtime components outside the namespace.
segment.target: The public modifier makes the class visible to Windows Runtime components outside the namespace.

segment.source: The sealed keyword means the class cannot serve as a base class.
segment.target: The sealed keyword means the class cannot serve as a base class.

segment.source: Almost all ref classes are sealed; class inheritance is not broadly used because Javascript does not understand it.
segment.target: Almost all ref classes are sealed; class inheritance is not broadly used because Javascript does not understand it.

segment.source: ref new and ^ (hats)
segment.target: ref new and ^ (hats)

segment.source: You declare a variable of a ref class by using the ^ (hat) operator, and you instantiate the object with the ref new keyword.
segment.target: You declare a variable of a ref class by using the ^ (hat) operator, and you instantiate the object with the ref new keyword.

segment.source: Thereafter you access the object's instance methods with the -> operator just like a C++ pointer.
segment.target: Thereafter you access the object's instance methods with the -> operator just like a C++ pointer.

segment.source: Static methods are accessed with the :: operator just as in ISO C++.
segment.target: Static methods are accessed with the :: operator just as in ISO C++.

segment.source: In the following code, we use the fully qualified name to instantiate an object, and use the -> operator to call an instance method.
segment.target: In the following code, we use the fully qualified name to instantiate an object, and use the -> operator to call an instance method.

segment.source: Typically, in a .cpp file we would add a using namespace Windows::UI::Xaml::Media::Imaging directive and the auto keyword, so that the same code would look like this:
segment.target: Typically, in a .cpp file we would add a using namespace Windows::UI::Xaml::Media::Imaging directive and the auto keyword, so that the same code would look like this:

segment.source: A ref class can have properties, which, just as in managed languages, are special member functions that appear as fields to consuming code.
segment.target: A ref class can have properties, which, just as in managed languages, are special member functions that appear as fields to consuming code.

segment.source: Just as in managed languages, a delegate is a reference type that encapsulates a function with a specific signature.
segment.target: Just as in managed languages, a delegate is a reference type that encapsulates a function with a specific signature.

segment.source: They are most often used with events and event handlers
segment.target: They are most often used with events and event handlers

segment.source: Adding content to the app
segment.target: Adding content to the app

segment.source: Let's add some content to the app.
segment.target: Let's add some content to the app.

segment.source: In Solution Explorer, open MainPage.xaml.
segment.target: In Solution Explorer, open MainPage.xaml.

segment.source: Create controls for the UI by adding the following XAML to the root **Grid**, immediately before its closing tag.
segment.target: Create controls for the UI by adding the following XAML to the root **Grid**, immediately before its closing tag.

segment.source: It contains a **StackPanel** that has a **TextBlock** that asks the user's name, a **TextBox** element that accepts the user's name, a **Button**, and another TextBlock element.
segment.target: It contains a **StackPanel** that has a **TextBlock** that asks the user's name, a **TextBox** element that accepts the user's name, a **Button**, and another TextBlock element.

segment.source: We talk more about XAML layout in the Navigation, layout, and views article.
segment.target: We talk more about XAML layout in the Navigation, layout, and views article.

segment.source: At this point, you have created a very basic Universal Windows app.
segment.target: At this point, you have created a very basic Universal Windows app.

segment.source: To see what the UWP app looks like, press F5 to build, deploy, and run the app in debugging mode.
segment.target: To see what the UWP app looks like, press F5 to build, deploy, and run the app in debugging mode.

segment.source: The default splash screen appears first.
segment.target: The default splash screen appears first.

segment.source: It has an image—Assets\\SplashScreen.scale-100.png—and a background color that are specified in the app's manifest file.
segment.target: It has an image—Assets\\SplashScreen.scale-100.png—and a background color that are specified in the app's manifest file.

segment.source: To learn how to customize the splash screen, see Adding a splash screen.
segment.target: To learn how to customize the splash screen, see Adding a splash screen.

segment.source: When the splash screen disappears, your app appears.
segment.target: When the splash screen disappears, your app appears.

segment.source: It displays the main page of the App.
segment.target: It displays the main page of the App.

segment.source: Press the Windows key or click the Start button to go to the Start menu, and notice that deploying the app adds it to the Start menu's list of installed apps.
segment.target: Press the Windows key or click the Start button to go to the Start menu, and notice that deploying the app adds it to the Start menu's list of installed apps.

segment.source: It also appears when you click on the the New link next to the All Apps button.
segment.target: It also appears when you click on the the New link next to the All Apps button.

segment.source: To run the app again, just tap or click its tile, press F5 or Ctrl+F5 in Visual Studio as usual.
segment.target: To run the app again, just tap or click its tile, press F5 or Ctrl+F5 in Visual Studio as usual.

source.pc: Windows Store app screen, with controls

target.pc: Windows Store app screen, with controls

segment.source: It doesn't do much—yet—but congratulations, you've built your first Universal Windows Platform app!
segment.target: It doesn't do much—yet—but congratulations, you've built your first Universal Windows Platform app!

segment.source: To stop debugging and close the app, return to Visual Studio and press Shift+F5.
segment.target: To stop debugging and close the app, return to Visual Studio and press Shift+F5.

segment.source: For more information, see Run a Store app from Visual Studio.
segment.target: For more information, see Run a Store app from Visual Studio.

segment.source: In the app, you can type in the **TextBox**, but clicking the **Button** doesn't do anything.
segment.target: In the app, you can type in the **TextBox**, but clicking the **Button** doesn't do anything.

segment.source: In later steps, you create an event handler for the button's **Click** event, which displays a personalized greeting.
segment.target: In later steps, you create an event handler for the button's **Click** event, which displays a personalized greeting.

segment.source: Start the app on a mobile device emulator
segment.target: Start the app on a mobile device emulator

segment.source: Your app runs on any Windows 10 device, so let’s see how it looks on a Windows Phone.
segment.target: Your app runs on any Windows 10 device, so let’s see how it looks on a Windows Phone.

segment.source: This section requires a Windows Phone running Windows 10, or access to a Windows Phone emulator and it requires that Visual Studio be running on a physical computer (not a virtual machine) with HyperV supported and enabled.
segment.target: This section requires a Windows Phone running Windows 10, or access to a Windows Phone emulator and it requires that Visual Studio be running on a physical computer (not a virtual machine) with HyperV supported and enabled.

segment.source: In addition to the options to debug on a desktop device, Visual Studio provides options for deploying and debugging your app on a physical mobile device connected to the computer, or on a mobile device emulator.
segment.target: In addition to the options to debug on a desktop device, Visual Studio provides options for deploying and debugging your app on a physical mobile device connected to the computer, or on a mobile device emulator.

segment.source: You can choose among emulators for devices with different memory and display configurations.
segment.target: You can choose among emulators for devices with different memory and display configurations.

segment.source: Various emulators in other configurations
segment.target: Various emulators in other configurations

segment.source: It's a good idea to test your app on a device with a small screen and limited memory, so use the Emulator 10.0.0.0 WVGA 4 inch 512MB option.
segment.target: It's a good idea to test your app on a device with a small screen and limited memory, so use the Emulator 10.0.0.0 WVGA 4 inch 512MB option.

segment.source: Tip For more info about using the phone emulator, see Run Windows Phone apps in the emulator.
segment.target: Tip For more info about using the phone emulator, see Run Windows Phone apps in the emulator.

segment.source: To debug your app on a physical device, you must have a device that’s registered for development.
segment.target: To debug your app on a physical device, you must have a device that’s registered for development.

segment.source: For more info, see Register your Windows Phone.
segment.target: For more info, see Register your Windows Phone.

source.pc: To start debugging on a mobile device emulator

target.pc: To start debugging on a mobile device emulator

segment.source: In the target device menu (Start debugging menu) on the Standard toolbar, pick Emulator 10.0.0.0 WVGA 4 inch 512MB.
segment.target: In the target device menu (Start debugging menu) on the Standard toolbar, pick Emulator 10.0.0.0 WVGA 4 inch 512MB.

segment.source: Click the Start Debugging button (Start debugging button) in the toolbar.
segment.target: Click the Start Debugging button (Start debugging button) in the toolbar.

segment.source: –or–
segment.target: –or–

segment.source: From the Debug menu, click Start Debugging.
segment.target: From the Debug menu, click Start Debugging.

segment.source: –or–
segment.target: –or–

segment.source: Press F5.
segment.target: Press F5.

segment.source: On the mobile device emulator, the app looks like this.
segment.target: On the mobile device emulator, the app looks like this.

source.pc: Initial app screen on mobile device

target.pc: Initial app screen on mobile device

segment.source: Visual Studio starts the selected emulator and then deploys and starts your app.
segment.target: Visual Studio starts the selected emulator and then deploys and starts your app.

segment.source: The first thing you'll notice is that the 120-pixel left margin that looks good on the local machine pushes your content off the smaller screen of a mobile device.
segment.target: The first thing you'll notice is that the 120-pixel left margin that looks good on the local machine pushes your content off the smaller screen of a mobile device.

segment.source: Later in this tutorial, you'll learn how to adapt the UI to different screen sizes so your app always looks good.
segment.target: Later in this tutorial, you'll learn how to adapt the UI to different screen sizes so your app always looks good.

segment.source: Step 2: Create an event handler
segment.target: Step 2: Create an event handler

segment.source: In MainPage.xaml, in either XAML or design view, select the "Say Hello" **Button** in the **StackPanel** you added earlier.
segment.target: In MainPage.xaml, in either XAML or design view, select the "Say Hello" **Button** in the **StackPanel** you added earlier.

segment.source: Open the Properties Window by pressing Alt+Enter, and then choose the Events button (Events button).
segment.target: Open the Properties Window by pressing Alt+Enter, and then choose the Events button (Events button).

segment.source: Find the **Click** event.
segment.target: Find the **Click** event.

segment.source: In its text box, type the name of the function that handles the Click event.
segment.target: In its text box, type the name of the function that handles the Click event.

segment.source: For this example, type "Button\_Click".
segment.target: For this example, type "Button\_Click".

segment.source: Press Enter.
segment.target: Press Enter.

segment.source: The event handler method is created in MainPage.xaml.cpp and opened so that you can add the code that's executed when the event occurs.
segment.target: The event handler method is created in MainPage.xaml.cpp and opened so that you can add the code that's executed when the event occurs.

segment.source: At the same time, in MainPage.xaml, the XAML for the **Button** is updated to declare the **Click** event handler, like this:
segment.target: At the same time, in MainPage.xaml, the XAML for the **Button** is updated to declare the **Click** event handler, like this:

segment.source: You could also have simply added this to the xaml code manually, which can be helpful if the designer doesn't load.
segment.target: You could also have simply added this to the xaml code manually, which can be helpful if the designer doesn't load.

segment.source: If you enter this manually, type "Click" and then let IntelliSense pop up the option to add a new event handler.
segment.target: If you enter this manually, type "Click" and then let IntelliSense pop up the option to add a new event handler.

segment.source: That way, Visual Studio creates the necessary method declaration and stub.
segment.target: That way, Visual Studio creates the necessary method declaration and stub.

segment.source: The designer fails to load if an unhandled exception occurs during rendering.
segment.target: The designer fails to load if an unhandled exception occurs during rendering.

segment.source: Rendering in the designer involves running a design-time version of the page.
segment.target: Rendering in the designer involves running a design-time version of the page.

segment.source: It can be helpful to disable running user code.
segment.target: It can be helpful to disable running user code.

segment.source: You can do this by changing the setting in the Tools, Options dialog box.
segment.target: You can do this by changing the setting in the Tools, Options dialog box.

segment.source: Under XAML Designer, uncheck Run project code in XAML designer (if supported).
segment.target: Under XAML Designer, uncheck Run project code in XAML designer (if supported).

segment.source: In MainPage.xaml.cpp, add the following code to the Button\_Click event handler that you just created.
segment.target: In MainPage.xaml.cpp, add the following code to the Button\_Click event handler that you just created.

segment.source: This code retrieves the user's name from the nameInput **TextBox** control and uses it to create a greeting.
segment.target: This code retrieves the user's name from the nameInput **TextBox** control and uses it to create a greeting.

segment.source: The greetingOutput **TextBlock** displays the result.
segment.target: The greetingOutput **TextBlock** displays the result.

segment.source: Set the project as the startup, and then press F5 to build and run the app.
segment.target: Set the project as the startup, and then press F5 to build and run the app.

segment.source: When you type a name in the text box and click the button, the app displays a personalized greeting.
segment.target: When you type a name in the text box and click the button, the app displays a personalized greeting.

segment.source: Step 3: Style the start page
segment.target: Step 3: Style the start page

segment.source: Choosing a theme
segment.target: Choosing a theme

segment.source: It's easy to customize the look and feel of your app.
segment.target: It's easy to customize the look and feel of your app.

segment.source: By default, your app uses resources that have a light style.
segment.target: By default, your app uses resources that have a light style.

segment.source: The system resources also include a light theme.
segment.target: The system resources also include a light theme.

segment.source: Let's try it out and see what it looks like.
segment.target: Let's try it out and see what it looks like.

source.pc: To switch to the dark theme

target.pc: To switch to the dark theme

segment.source: Open App.xaml.
segment.target: Open App.xaml.

segment.source: In the opening **Application** tag, edit the **RequestedTheme** property and set its value to Dark:
segment.target: In the opening **Application** tag, edit the **RequestedTheme** property and set its value to Dark:

segment.source: Here's the full **Application** tag with the dark theme :
segment.target: Here's the full **Application** tag with the dark theme :

segment.source: Press F5 to build and run it.
segment.target: Press F5 to build and run it.

segment.source: Notice that it uses the dark theme.
segment.target: Notice that it uses the dark theme.

segment.source: Which theme should you use?
segment.target: Which theme should you use?

segment.source: Whichever one you want.
segment.target: Whichever one you want.

segment.source: Here's our take: for apps that mostly display images or video, we recommend the dark theme; for apps that contain a lot of text, we recommend the light theme.
segment.target: Here's our take: for apps that mostly display images or video, we recommend the dark theme; for apps that contain a lot of text, we recommend the light theme.

segment.source: If you're using a custom color scheme, use the theme that goes best with your app's look and feel.
segment.target: If you're using a custom color scheme, use the theme that goes best with your app's look and feel.

segment.source: In the rest of this tutorial, we use the Light theme in screenshots.
segment.target: In the rest of this tutorial, we use the Light theme in screenshots.

segment.source: Note The theme is applied when the app is started and can't be changed while the app is running.
segment.target: Note The theme is applied when the app is started and can't be changed while the app is running.

segment.source: Using system styles
segment.target: Using system styles

segment.source: Right now, in the Windows app the text is very small and difficult to read.
segment.target: Right now, in the Windows app the text is very small and difficult to read.

segment.source: Let's fix that by applying a system style.
segment.target: Let's fix that by applying a system style.

source.pc: To change the style of an element

target.pc: To change the style of an element

segment.source: In the Windows project, open MainPage.xaml.
segment.target: In the Windows project, open MainPage.xaml.

segment.source: In either XAML or design view, select the "What's your name?"**TextBlock** that you added earlier.
segment.target: In either XAML or design view, select the "What's your name?"**TextBlock** that you added earlier.

segment.source: In the Properties window (F4), choose the Properties button (Properties button) in the upper right.
segment.target: In the Properties window (F4), choose the Properties button (Properties button) in the upper right.

segment.source: Expand the Text group and set the font size to 18 px.
segment.target: Expand the Text group and set the font size to 18 px.

segment.source: Expand the Miscellaneous group and find the Style property.
segment.target: Expand the Miscellaneous group and find the Style property.

segment.source: Click the property marker (the green box to the right of the Style property), and then, on the menu, choose System Resource > BaseTextBlockStyle.
segment.target: Click the property marker (the green box to the right of the Style property), and then, on the menu, choose System Resource > BaseTextBlockStyle.

segment.source: BaseTextBlockStyle is a resource that's defined in the **ResourceDictionary** in \\Program Files\\Windows Kits\\10\\Include\\winrt\\xaml\\design\\generic.xaml.
segment.target: BaseTextBlockStyle is a resource that's defined in the **ResourceDictionary** in \\Program Files\\Windows Kits\\10\\Include\\winrt\\xaml\\design\\generic.xaml.

segment.source: On the XAML design surface, the appearance of the text changes.
segment.target: On the XAML design surface, the appearance of the text changes.

segment.source: In the XAML editor, the XAML for the **TextBlock** is updated:
segment.target: In the XAML editor, the XAML for the **TextBlock** is updated:

segment.source: Repeat the process to set the font size and assign the BaseTextBlockStyle to the greetingOutput**TextBlock** element.
segment.target: Repeat the process to set the font size and assign the BaseTextBlockStyle to the greetingOutput**TextBlock** element.

segment.source: Tip Although there's no text in this **TextBlock**, when you move the pointer over the XAML design surface, a blue outline shows where it is so that you can select it.
segment.target: Tip Although there's no text in this **TextBlock**, when you move the pointer over the XAML design surface, a blue outline shows where it is so that you can select it.

segment.source: Your XAML now looks like this:
segment.target: Your XAML now looks like this:

segment.source: Press F5 to build and run the app.
segment.target: Press F5 to build and run the app.

segment.source: It now looks like this:
segment.target: It now looks like this:

segment.source: Step 4: Adapt the UI to different window sizes
segment.target: Step 4: Adapt the UI to different window sizes

segment.source: Now we'll make the UI adapt to different screen sizes so it looks good on mobile devices.
segment.target: Now we'll make the UI adapt to different screen sizes so it looks good on mobile devices.

segment.source: To do this, you add a **VisualStateManager** and set properties that are applied for different visual states.
segment.target: To do this, you add a **VisualStateManager** and set properties that are applied for different visual states.

segment.source: In the XAML editor, add this block of XAML after the opening tag of the root **Grid** element.
segment.target: In the XAML editor, add this block of XAML after the opening tag of the root **Grid** element.

segment.source: Debug the app on the local machine.
segment.target: Debug the app on the local machine.

segment.source: Notice that the UI looks the same as before unless the window gets narrower than 641 device-independent pixels (DIPs).
segment.target: Notice that the UI looks the same as before unless the window gets narrower than 641 device-independent pixels (DIPs).

segment.source: Debug the app on the mobile device emulator.
segment.target: Debug the app on the mobile device emulator.

segment.source: Notice that the UI uses the properties you defined in the narrowState and appears correctly on the small screen.
segment.target: Notice that the UI uses the properties you defined in the narrowState and appears correctly on the small screen.

source.pc: Mobile app screen with styled text

target.pc: Mobile app screen with styled text

segment.source: If you've used a **VisualStateManager** in previous versions of XAML, you might notice that the XAML here uses a simplified syntax.
segment.target: If you've used a **VisualStateManager** in previous versions of XAML, you might notice that the XAML here uses a simplified syntax.

segment.source: The **VisualState** named wideState has an **AdaptiveTrigger** with its **MinWindowWidth** property set to 641.
segment.target: The **VisualState** named wideState has an **AdaptiveTrigger** with its **MinWindowWidth** property set to 641.

segment.source: This means that the state is to be applied only when the window width is not less than the minimum of 641 DIPs.
segment.target: This means that the state is to be applied only when the window width is not less than the minimum of 641 DIPs.

segment.source: You don't define any **Setter** objects for this state, so it uses the layout properties you defined in the XAML for the page content.
segment.target: You don't define any **Setter** objects for this state, so it uses the layout properties you defined in the XAML for the page content.

segment.source: The second **VisualState**, narrowState, has an **AdaptiveTrigger** with its **MinWindowWidth** property set to 0.
segment.target: The second **VisualState**, narrowState, has an **AdaptiveTrigger** with its **MinWindowWidth** property set to 0.

segment.source: This state is applied when the window width is greater than 0, but less than 641 DIPs.
segment.target: This state is applied when the window width is greater than 0, but less than 641 DIPs.

segment.source: (At 641 DIPs, the wideState is applied.)
segment.target: (At 641 DIPs, the wideState is applied.)

segment.source: In this state, you do define some **Setter** objects to change the layout properties of controls in the UI:
segment.target: In this state, you do define some **Setter** objects to change the layout properties of controls in the UI:

segment.source: You reduce the left margin of the contentPanel element from 120 to 20.
segment.target: You reduce the left margin of the contentPanel element from 120 to 20.

segment.source: You change the **Orientation** of the inputPanel element from Horizontal to Vertical.
segment.target: You change the **Orientation** of the inputPanel element from Horizontal to Vertical.

segment.source: You add a top margin of 4 DIPs to the inputButton element.
segment.target: You add a top margin of 4 DIPs to the inputButton element.

segment.source: Summary
segment.target: Summary

segment.source: Congratulations, you've completed the first tutorial!
segment.target: Congratulations, you've completed the first tutorial!

segment.source: It taught how to add content to Windows Universal apps, how to add interactivity to them, and how to change their appearance.
segment.target: It taught how to add content to Windows Universal apps, how to add interactivity to them, and how to change their appearance.

segment.source: Next steps
segment.target: Next steps

segment.source: If you have a Windows Universal app project that targets Windows 8.1 and/or Windows Phone 8.1, you can port it to Windows 10.
segment.target: If you have a Windows Universal app project that targets Windows 8.1 and/or Windows Phone 8.1, you can port it to Windows 10.

segment.source: There is no automatic process for this, but you can do it manually with a little effort.
segment.target: There is no automatic process for this, but you can do it manually with a little effort.

segment.source: Start with a new Windows Universal project to get the latest project system structure and manifest files, copy your code files into the project's directory structure, add the items to your project, and rewrite your XAML using the **VisualStateManager** according to the guidance in this topic.
segment.target: Start with a new Windows Universal project to get the latest project system structure and manifest files, copy your code files into the project's directory structure, add the items to your project, and rewrite your XAML using the **VisualStateManager** according to the guidance in this topic.

segment.source: For more information, see Porting a Windows Runtime 8 project to a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) project and Porting to the Universal Windows Platform (C++).
segment.target: For more information, see Porting a Windows Runtime 8 project to a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) project and Porting to the Universal Windows Platform (C++).

segment.source: If you have existing C++ code that you want to integrate with a UWP app, such as to create a new UWP UI for an existing application, see How to: Use existing C++ code in a Universal Windows project.
segment.target: If you have existing C++ code that you want to integrate with a UWP app, such as to create a new UWP UI for an existing application, see How to: Use existing C++ code in a Universal Windows project.
